title: 4429 Chinmoy
text:
4429 Chinmoy, provisional designation , is a Nysian <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> from the inner regions of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>, approximately in diameter. It was discovered on 12 September 1978, by Soviet astronomer <a href="Nikolai%20Chernykh">Nikolai Chernykh</a> at the <a href="Crimean%20Astrophysical%20Observatory">Crimean Astrophysical Observatory</a> in Nauchnij, on the Crimean Peninsula. The likely <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-type asteroid</a> was named after Indian spiritual leader <a href="Sri%20Chinmoy">Sri Chinmoy</a>.
Orbit and classification.
"Chinmoy" is a member of the <a href="Nysa%20family">Nysa family</a> (), one of the largest <a href="asteroid%20families">asteroid families</a> and part of the <a href="Nysa%E2%80%93Polana%20complex">Nysa–Polana complex</a> with nearly 20 thousand identified members.
It orbits the Sun in the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">inner</a> main-belt at a distance of 1.9–2.9 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 3 years and 8 months (1,341 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 2.38 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.21 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 1<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>.
The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins with a <a href="precovery">precovery</a> taken at <a href="Palomar%20Observatory">Palomar Observatory</a> in February 1954, more than 24 years prior to its official discovery observation at Nauchnij.
Physical characteristics.
"Chinmoy" has an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 14.6. While its <a href="Asteroid%20spectral%20type">spectral type</a> has not been determined, it is likely a stony <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-type asteroid</a> based on its membership to the Nysa family and its albedo "(see below)". As of 2018, no rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Chinmoy" has been obtained from <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations. The body's <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a>, <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">pole</a> and shape remain unknown.
Diameter and albedo.
According to the survey carried out by the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a>, "Chinmoy" measures 3.498 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of 0.229.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named after Indian spiritual leader <a href="Sri%20Chinmoy">Sri Chinmoy</a> (1931–2007). The official naming citation was published by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 25 April 1994 ().
External links.
